name: Orangecubegames.GitHub.io
body:
# Welcome to the main OCG Website! #
## Who we are ##
> Orange Cube Games ( referred to as OCG from now on ) is a group of friends that decided to make games for fun. Currently > there are 4 members of OCG, and 3 members of the sub-divisional group OCS ( Orange Cube Studios, the people who make our > websites look slightly more professional then the OCG itself, they also make music for our games and manage our social > networks ).
>> OCG mainly focuses on bringing back the 20th century games back to modern life. We also specialize in 16&32-bit games, >> however we also do games-on-request.
## Our games so far ##
> We are currently working on 3 major projects ( listed in order )
>> ### Absolut ###
_RTS zombie survival game._ Planned release: Late February 2015 - Mid March 2015
>> ### Double Helix ###
_A puzzle-based RPG._ Planned release: Late April 2015 - Late June 2015
>> ### RPG ###
_The most meta RPG to exist._ Planned release: Late September - Late October 2015
>>> Between release dates we'll be working on updates and/or smaller projects in Flash; and not in our Game Engine.
## Our Game Engine ##
> We have two game engines to date; as listed below.
>> ### OE - Orange Engine ###
>>> Focuses on quicker projects that are highly customizable; however it lacks in many key features ( such as animation and multiplayer compatibility ).
>> ### CO - Comedy Orange ###
>>> A packet of dll's that are used in other game engines ( such as Unity ), and a couple of JAR's for Java games ( which we used to do, until some issues with the formats we use and how inefficient / demanding Java is.
## Places of release ##
> ### Steam Store ###
( Mainly Greenlight, unless Valve feels nice )
> ### This website ###
Under **/games/**; there will be links to the code.google.com repo's. _Disclamer: We post the DEMO's and/or BETA's of the game there if the game gets on Steam. If it doesn't then we'll be only posting BETA's there ( until the game is good enough to get on Greenlight )._
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
